title: The Morning Risk Report: Revamped IMF Framework ‘Adds Teeth’ to Corruption Fight - Risk & Compliance Journal. - WSJ
text:

International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde speaks to reporters in Washington on April 20. AP Photo/Jose Luis Magana Good morning. The International Monetary Fund updated its framework for dealing with governance and corruption issues in its annual economic assessments of countries; the changes will pressure countries to demonstrate improvement in their anti-corruption efforts.
The revisions announced earlier this month are the first changes to the framework since it took effect in 1997. They will focus on fiscal governance, financial sector oversight, central bank governance and public contracts, an IMF spokesman told Risk & Compliance Journal on Friday. “We are trying to help governments address those vulnerabilities so they can try to improve the perception and the reality of their governance with their legal and overall business framework,” the spokesman said.
A review of the 1997 policy conducted last year found the IMF was uneven in its use of the framework during assessments, and “there remained several areas in which the IMF’s engagement on governance and corruption issues can be strengthened,” the organization said in a statement. Member governments requested help from the IMF to help in the fight against corruption; the spokesman said there was “strong support” to look into those issues. “There definitely was a strong mandate to deal with those issues more forcefully, directly and systematically,” he said.
The revised framework demonstrates not only the IMF’s commitment to the transnational fight against corruption, but it also puts “real teeth” into the inquiries it will make of governments, said Tom Fox, a compliance attorney, commentator and author of the just-released “Complete Compliance Handbook.”
In addition to assessing the laws a country has in place, Mr. Fox said the IMF will look at “pinch points where regulators can put out their hands for payment.” It also specified “private actors” should focus “on measures designed to prevent the private actors from offering bribes or providing services that facilitate concealment of corruption proceeds.”
The updated assessment is “far beyond” what the IMF had in place in 1997, said Mr. Fox. “This two-pronged approach is not only far more robust than the 1997 approach but will tie both the supply side and demand side together for a more robust transactional analysis to the problem of bribery and corruption,” he said.
Anticorruption organization Transparency International called the new framework “a major step forward.” The group said, however, it would closely monitor new IMF country reports to see if they will include basic findings on corruption risks; how the IMF will assess so-called “spillover countries” and whether the IMF will seek help from non-governmental organizations when conducting assessments.
“If properly implemented, this new framework could mean a significant shift in the IMF’s engagement with anticorruption,” Transparency International said Friday.
EXCLUSIVE ON RISK AND COMPLIANCE JOURNAL
U.S. places sanctions on suspected fentanyl distributor. The U.S. Treasury Department imposed sanctions on an alleged Chinese distributor of fentanyl, the company he owns and four people accused of laundering the drug money.
Jian Zhang was charged in October with running a drug network that manufactured and directly shipped thousands of doses of fentanyl to U.S. consumers through the Internet. Mr. Zhang used a Hong Kong-registered company called Zaron Bio-tech to create fentanyl in at least four labs in China, and advertised and sold the drug online since 2013, prosecutors said at the time.
Mr. Zhang’s network directly contributed to American deaths in the opioid crisis, Treasury said Friday . “Combating the flow of fentanyl into the United States is a top priority of this administration,” said Sigal Mandelker, undersecretary of Treasury for terrorism and financial intelligence.
The sanctions announced Friday targeted Mr. Zhang, the company and four Chinese nationals Treasury said conducted financial transactions through money-service businesses to launder drug proceeds. Federal prosecutors on Friday announced charges on the same four Chinese people and six Americans. — Samuel Rubenfeld
Utility’s compliance chief speaks on whistleblowing. Antonio Fernández, chief compliance officer at Public Service Enterprise Group Inc. , discusses encouraging whistleblowers to speak up and how the rise of social media has affected compliance.
COMPLIANCE
U.S. takes on fuel-economy regulations. U.S. regulators want to halt plans to keep raising fuel-economy standards and are proposing ways to strip California’s ability to go its own way. Officials have drafted a proposal on how the government could prevent California from setting stricter limits than Washington on pollution from vehicles, the WSJ reports.
Oil-well rule faces revisions. U.S. regulators this week will unveil proposed changes to a major rule passed in the wake of the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster, which the Trump administration says it can revise to be less costly for offshore oil drillers without compromising safety, the WSJ reports.
China eases rules for foreign fund managers. China will give foreign money managers greater access to raise funds from domestic investors. Guidelines released over the weekend gave formal authorization for foreign firms to control 51% of a local securities joint venture, up from 49%. That cap would be removed in three years. The changes are effective now, the WSJ reports.
Judge halts Xeroxle. Xerox Corp. ’s deal to sell a majority of itself to Fujifilm Holdings was temporarily blocked by a judge who said the transaction was negotiated by a chief executive who was looking out for his own interests over Xerox shareholders’, the WSJ reports. Xerox investors Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason are fighting the deal.
Deripaska to cut stake in EN+. Oleg Deripaska agreed to sell down his majority stake in EN+ Group PLC, the company that owns 48% of aluminum giant United Co. Rusal . The move could help Rusal and EN+ to escape U.S. Treasury sanctions by distancing them from Mr. Deripaska, seen as an ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin, the WSJ reports.
EN+ said Oleg Deripaska will pare his majority holding to below 50%, but the company didn’t identify a buyer. EN+ said Oleg Deripaska will pare his majority holding to below 50%, but the company didn’t identify a buyer. PHOTO: SERGEI KARPUKHIN/REUTERS AT&T antitrust cases is slog for U.S. The Justice Department’s case against AT&T ’s planned acquisition of Time Warner Inc. has shown signs of strain after a grueling trial, highlighting the difficulty of challenging a merger involving companies that aren’t direct competitors, the WSJ reports. Closing arguments are set for Monday.
GOVERNANCE
Aramco shakes up its board. Saudi state-oil giant Aramco added five members including its first female director, to its board of directors as it prepares to list its stock. Aramco said Sunday it was adding three non-Saudi members, including Lynn Laverty Elsenhans, the former chief executive of U.S. oil refiner Sunoco Inc., the WSJ reports
Samsung to overhaul structure. Samsung plans to drastically simplify the conglomerate’s ownership structure in coming months, the WSJ reports, untangling a controversial web that has long been criticized for benefiting the controlling Lee family at the expense of minority shareholders.
REPUTATION
Steve Wynn sues ex-employee. Steve Wynn, the former chief executive of Wynn Resorts Ltd. , filed a defamation lawsuit this week against a former Wynn Resorts employee, alleging that he smeared Mr. Wynn by spreading false accusations of alleged sexual misconduct in media reports, the WSJ reports.
Brokaw denies harassment allegation. Tom Brokaw vigorously denied an allegation of sexual harassment made by former NBC reporter Linda Vester, calling her an “angry” ex-colleague with a grudge against NBC News who is out to destroy his family and career, the WSJ reports. A lawyer for Ms. Vester said she stands by her allegation.
Ex-staffer fights back against BofA. Omeed Malik, the fired Bank of America Corp. executive at the center of a sexual-misconduct probe, filed a defamation claim against the bank, according to his attorney. The claim asks the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority for a more than $100 million award. The bank said the claim is without merit, the WSJ reports.
RISK
Pyongyang to close test site by May. North Korea said it would shut down its nuclear test site by May and take steps to demonstrate the closure to the world, South Korea’s presidential office said Sunday, adding to momentum for a deal on the regime’s nuclear program after last week’s historic talks between the two sides, the WSJ reports.
OPERATIONS
Retail trouble: too few clerks in stores. Many of America’s biggest retailers, under assault from Amazon.com, have been slashing staff even faster than they have been closing stores, a dynamic that has left fewer clerks and longer checkout lines at remaining locations, the WSJ reports.
STRATEGY
T-Mobile agrees to buy Sprint. T-Mobile US Inc. struck a $26 billion deal to buy Sprint Corp. in a combination that, if allowed by antitrust enforcers, would leave the U.S. wireless market dominated by three national players. It is the third time in the last four years the two rivals have attempted the combination, the WSJ reports.
Marathon Petroleum to buy Andeavor. Marathon Petroleum Corp. plans to buy pipeline and refining company Andeavor for more than $20 billion, the WSJ reports. The cash-and-stock deal, which values Andeavor at $152.27 a share, was announced Monday.
Walmart to merge British arm with Sainsbury. Walmart said it would sell its British arm Asda Group Ltd. to rival J Sainsbury PLC , a deal that values the chain at about £7.3 billion ($10.1 billion). Walmart would have a 42% stake in the combined company, the WSJ reports.
Customers arrive to go shopping at a branch of Asda supermarket in south London. PHOTO: JUSTIN TALLIS/AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE/GETTY IMAGES Prologis to acquire DCT Industrial Trust. Prologis Inc. agreed to buy logistics-property owner DCT Industrial Trust Inc. for $8.4 billion including debt, as a surge in e-commerce ramps up demand for warehouses and distribution centers, the WSJ reports.

A more harmonized and integrated enterprise compliance program, one that includes risk management activities and controls for the supply chain, can help improve compliance efforts. In addition, organizations may want to assess core supply chain management issues that are considered sources of compliance challenges, including transparency in product origin, as well as communication across the organization.
